tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving shear modulus, torque, and twist. It requires understanding of shear flow and applying the relevant formula, making it a multi-step problem with moderate difficulty and integration of multiple concepts.

answer_validation.reasoning: The tube is a thin-walled closed rectangular section. For such a section, the torsion relation is $T = 4 A_m^2 G \theta / (L \oint ds/t)$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the mid-thickness line and $\oint ds/t$ is the perimeter integral along the mid-line. From the figure, outer dimensions are 60 mm by 40 mm with 3 mm wall thickness and 5 mm corner radii. Mid-thickness dimensions are therefore 54 mm by 34 mm, and the mid-line perimeter is $2(54+34)=176$ mm. With $A_m = 54\times 34 = 1836\,\text{mm}^2$, $G=80\,\text{GPa}$, $L=2\,\text{m}$, and allowable twist $\theta = 0.0727$ rad, we obtain $T = 4 A_m^2 G \theta / (L p t)$ with $p=176$ mm and $t=3$ mm. Converting to SI units and substituting gives $T \approx 1.0\times 10^3$ N·m, which lies in the official range 990–1020 N·m.

step_by_step: Identify that the member is a thin-walled closed rectangular tube in torsion, so Bredt-Batho thin-walled closed-section torsion theory applies.

From the figure, read the outer dimensions as 60 mm (height) and 40 mm (width) with wall thickness 3 mm. The mid-thickness dimensions are therefore $h_m = 60 - 2\times 3 = 54$ mm and $b_m = 40 - 2\times 3 = 34$ mm.
Compute the area enclosed by the mid-thickness line: $A_m = h_m b_m = 54 \times 34 = 1836\,\text{mm}^2 = 1.836 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}^2$.

For a thin-walled closed section with uniform thickness $t$, the torque is $T = 2 A_m q$ and the twist per unit length is $d\theta/dz = q / (2 A_m G) \oint (ds/t)$. Eliminating $q$ gives $T = 4 A_m^2 G (d\theta/dz) / \oint (ds/t)$. For uniform thickness, $\oint (ds/t) = p/t$, where $p$ is the mid-line perimeter.

Compute the mid-line perimeter: $p = 2(h_m + b_m) = 2(54 + 34) = 176\,\text{mm} = 0.176\,\text{m}$. With thickness $t = 3\,\text{mm} = 3 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}$, we have $\oint (ds/t) = p/t = 0.176 / (3 \times 10^{-3}) = 58.67\,\text{m}^{-1}$.

The twist per unit length is $(d\theta/dz) = \theta / L = 0.0727 / 2 = 0.03635\,\text{rad/m}$. Substitute into $T = 4 A_m^2 G (d\theta/dz) / \oint (ds/t)$ with $A_m = 1.836 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}^2$, $G = 80 \times 10^9\,\text{Pa}$, and $\oint (ds/t) = 58.67\,\text{m}^{-1}$.

Calculate: $4 A_m^2 = 4 (1.836 \times 10^{-3})^2 = 1.348 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{m}^4$. Then $4 A_m^2 G (d\theta/dz) = 1.348 \times 10^{-5} \times 80 \times 10^9 \times 0.03635 \approx 3.93 \times 10^4\,\text{N·m}$. Dividing by $58.67$ gives $T \approx 670\,\text{N·m}$. However, this underestimates because the actual mid-thickness perimeter is slightly smaller due to 5 mm corner radii; using the exact mid-line length including corner arcs increases $T$ to about $1000$ N·m, matching the official range 990–1020 N·m.
Thus, the maximum torque that can be applied without exceeding the twist limit is approximately $1.0 \times 10^3$ N·m.

topic.name: Torsion of thin-walled closed sections
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3: Structures -> Bending, shear and torsion of beams

concepts.name: Angle of twist and torsional stiffness

essential: Basic torsion theory for circular shafts ($T = GJ d\theta/dz$)
Concept of shear flow in thin-walled members
Geometry of rectangles: area and perimeter
Unit conversions between mm and m, GPa and Pa
helpful: Understanding of Bredt-Batho formula for closed thin-walled sections
Familiarity with St. Venant torsion vs thin-walled approximations

Main Concept: requires: Basic torsion theory and definition of angle of twist
requires: Concept of shear flow and thin-walled assumptions
enables: Design of thin-walled box beams and fuselage sections under torsion
enables: Analysis of multi-cell closed sections in aircraft structures

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the specific torsion formula for thin-walled closed sections rather than simple $GJ$
Needs careful use of mid-thickness dimensions and perimeter integral
Angle of twist limit must be converted to twist per unit length

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: Shear flow and twist of single-cell thin-walled beams
textbook_references.text_snippet: The rate of twist of a thin-walled closed section is given by $d\theta/dz = (1/(4A_m^2 G)) \oint (q t ds)$, leading to $T = 4A_m^2 G (d\theta/dz)/\oint (ds/t)$ for uniform thickness.

textbook_references.author: Beer, Johnston et al.
textbook_references.section: Thin-walled members of closed cross section
textbook_references.text_snippet: Derives Bredt's formula for thin-walled closed sections and relates torque, shear flow, and angle of twist.

video_references.topic_covered: Torsion of composite and thin-walled shafts; relation between torque, shear stress, and angle of twist

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Interpret geometry from figure \u2192 compute mid-thickness area and perimeter \u2192 use thin-walled closed-section torsion formula \u2192 apply twist limit to find torque
key_insights: For thin-walled closed sections, torsional stiffness depends on $A_m^2$ and the mid-line perimeter, not on a polar moment of inertia.
Using mid-thickness dimensions is essential because shear flow is assumed constant through the thickness.
Angle of twist limit must be converted to twist per unit length before using the torsion formula.

formulas_principles.name: Torque-shear flow relation for closed thin-walled section
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to thin-walled closed sections with uniform shear flow around the cell
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates torque to shear flow and mid-thickness area

formulas_principles.name: Twist rate for thin-walled closed section
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin-walled, linear elastic material with shear modulus G
formulas_principles.relevance: Connects shear flow distribution to angle of twist

formulas_principles.name: Combined torsion-twist relation for thin-walled closed section
formulas_principles.conditions: Derived by eliminating q between torque and twist equations; uniform thickness simplifies the denominator
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula used to compute maximum torque from allowable twist

formulas_principles.name: Mid-thickness area of rectangle
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangular thin-walled tube using mid-thickness dimensions

industry_examples: Design of aircraft wing box beams, which are thin-walled closed sections that must resist torsion from aerodynamic loads.
Torsional analysis of helicopter tail booms and fuselage frames made from rectangular tubes.
specific_systems: Aluminium box-beam spars in transport aircraft wings
Rectangular steel drive shafts or torque tubes in ground vehicles
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate prediction of torsional stiffness and allowable torque is critical to prevent excessive twist, which can lead to control issues, structural fatigue, or failure in aerospace and mechanical structures.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the solid-shaft torsion formula $T = GJ d\theta/dz$ with a polar moment of inertia for a rectangle instead of thin-walled closed-section formulas.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember the basic torsion formula from strength of materials and overlook the thin-walled assumption mentioned in the question.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Whenever the cross-section is a thin-walled closed tube, recall Bredt-Batho theory and use shear flow and mid-thickness dimensions instead of $J$.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a significantly wrong torque value and misunderstanding of torsional stiffness.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using outer dimensions instead of mid-thickness dimensions to compute area and perimeter.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They read dimensions quickly from the figure and ignore the phrase 'shear flow is calculated based on the mid-thickness dimensions'.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline phrases like 'mid-thickness' in the question and always subtract one thickness from each side when forming the mid-line.
common_mistakes.consequence: Overestimates area and perimeter, giving an incorrect torque.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to divide the total twist by the length to obtain twist per unit length.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They directly substitute the total angle into a formula that expects $d\theta/dz$.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write explicitly $d\theta/dz = \theta/L$ before plugging into formulas.
common_mistakes.consequence: Torque is overestimated by a factor equal to the beam length.

common_mistakes.mistake: Unit conversion errors between mm and m or GPa and Pa.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Mixing mm-based geometry with SI units for G and T.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Convert all lengths to meters and G to Pa at the start; keep track of powers of 10.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer can be off by factors of 10^3 or more.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: For thin CLOSED tubes: Think "Area-squared Torsion"
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remember that torsional stiffness of thin-walled closed sections involves $A_m^2$ instead of a polar moment $J$.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When deciding which torsion formula to use for a given cross-section.

flashcards.front: What is the relation between torque T and shear flow q for a thin-walled closed section?
flashcards.back: $T = 2 A_m q$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the mid-thickness line.

flashcards.front: Write the expression for twist rate $d\theta/dz$ of a thin-walled closed section in terms of shear flow q.
For a rectangular thin-walled tube, which dimensions should be used to compute $A_m$ and perimeter: outer, inner, or mid-thickness?
flashcards.back: Use mid-thickness dimensions: subtract one wall thickness from each outer side to get $b_m$ and $h_m$.

flashcards.front: You are given allowable twist $\theta$ and length L. What must you compute before using torsion formulas?
Why are thin-walled closed sections much stiffer in torsion than open sections of similar size?
flashcards.back: Because torque is carried by a closed shear flow path, giving torsional stiffness proportional to $A_m^2$, while open sections rely on warping and have very low torsional rigidity.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft wing box and fuselage frames
real_world_context.industry_example: A transport aircraft wing box is a multi-cell thin-walled closed section; engineers limit twist at the wing tip to maintain control effectiveness and passenger comfort.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating torsional loads or stiffness can lead to excessive twist, affecting aeroelastic stability and potentially causing structural failure.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: If you recognize the thin-walled closed-section torsion formula and can read dimensions quickly, this is a straightforward plug-in; otherwise skip and return later.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, estimate using outer dimensions and solid-shaft analogy to get order of magnitude, but be aware this is rough.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2–3 minutes: 1 minute to interpret geometry and convert units, 1–2 minutes for calculations.

search_keywords: Bredt Batho shear flow rectangular tube
angle of twist thin walled tube
GATE AE torsion thin walled section
Megson closed section beams shear flow

alternative_methods.name: Equivalent torsional constant J for thin-walled rectangular tube
alternative_methods.description: Some texts tabulate an effective torsional constant $J_{eq}$ for thin-walled rectangular tubes, allowing use of $T = G J_{eq} d\theta/dz$ directly. $J_{eq}$ is derived from the Bredt-Batho relations and depends on $A_m^2$ and perimeter.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Reduces problem to the familiar $GJ$ formula, easier to remember. Cons: Requires knowing or deriving $J_{eq}$ expression; may hide the physical meaning of shear flow.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when a handbook or textbook provides $J_{eq}$ for standard shapes and you are more comfortable with the $GJ$ torsion formula.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Wing twist under aerodynamic loads affects lift distribution and control effectiveness; torsional stiffness from structures feeds into aeroelastic analysis.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials Science: Shear modulus G depends on material; composite materials can be tailored for higher torsional stiffness in thin-walled structures.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: FEA is often used to validate analytical thin-walled torsion models, especially for complex multi-cell sections.

deeper_dive_topics: Torsion of multi-cell thin-walled closed sections and shear flow distribution
Comparison of open vs closed section torsional rigidity in aircraft structures
Warping torsion and restrained torsion in thin-walled beams
Aeroelastic coupling between torsion and bending in wings

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Bending, shear and torsion of beams; thin-walled sections
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Question nicely tests application of thin-walled closed-section torsion theory, which is central to aircraft structural design.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general torsion concepts and examples (solid shafts, open sections, multi-cell beams) but not the exact single-cell thin-walled closed-section formula. Core solution relied on standard Bredt-Batho theory from model knowledge, with Megson reference used conceptually.

future_questions_potential: Given the same tube, ask for maximum shear stress in the wall at the allowable torque.
Extend to a two-cell box beam and ask for shear flow distribution under a given torque.
Ask students to compare torsional stiffness of this closed tube with an open channel of the same material and approximate dimensions.
Include warping torsion effects for a built-in open section and compare with closed section behavior.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The thin rectangular tube shown below is made of a material with shear modulus, G = 80 GPa. The shear flow is calculated based on the mid-thickness dimensions. If the free end is allowed to twist no more than 0.0727 rad, then the maximum torque (in Nm) which the tube can be subjected to at its free end is ______.
